headline: Trump would still beat Harris or Biden in election rematch | Opinion
context: I realize this may blow Democrats' minds, but 100 days into President Donald Trump’s second term, most of the millions of Americans who cast their vote for him are still happy they did.
And Trump has not been twiddling his thumbs in these first months back in the Oval Office.

annotations.paragraph: There’s plenty to like or dislike, from his large number of executive orders to his federal cost-cutting bonanza with Tesla CEO Elon Musk.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific actions taken by Trump, contributing to the narrative of his presidency.

annotations.paragraph: So, it’s telling that a recent poll shows the vast majority of Trump supporters would vote for him again now, if given the opportunity for a do-over.
annotations.reason: This paragraph presents a poll result that directly supports the article's premise about Trump's continued support.

annotations.paragraph: And significantly more people are happy with the direction of the country now than they were before Trump took office. The gap between those who think the country is on the wrong track and those who think it's on the right track shrank from 36 points in November to fewer than 12 now.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides statistical data on public opinion, relevant to the article's focus on Trump's popularity.

annotations.paragraph: Trump is delivering on what he said he would do, and, for the most part, his voters appreciate it.
annotations.reason: This paragraph summarizes Trump's fulfillment of promises, relevant to the article's discussion of his support.

annotations.paragraph: Within weeks, Trump secured the border that his predecessor, Joe Biden, had left wide open. The Trump administration also is deporting illegal immigrants with criminal records.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific policy actions taken by Trump, relevant to the article's focus on his presidency.

annotations.paragraph: On economic matters, Trump is following through in a big way with his promise of tariffs, and polls show that he’s testing how far inflation-weary Americans are willing to endure the president’s risky gamble.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific information about Trump's economic policies and their impact on public opinion.

annotations.paragraph: As tariffs (and the subsequent threat of much higher prices) have become a reality, Trump’s approval numbers have dropped since he took office, even when it comes to the economy – a traditionally strong category for him.
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers relevant information about the effect of tariffs on Trump's approval ratings.

annotations.paragraph: So while Trump should not ignore the warning signs, it’s far from all bad news 100 days in.
annotations.reason: This paragraph is vague and does not provide specific information or context.

annotations.paragraph: A president’s approval numbers are usually mercurial, and move up and down depending on what’s happened in recent days. That’s why a poll from this month caught my eye.
annotations.reason: This paragraph is a general statement about approval ratings and does not add specific information.

annotations.paragraph: A University of Massachusetts Amherst/YouGov poll released April 14 asked voters how they felt about their presidential choice, three months into Trump’s term.
annotations.reason: This paragraph introduces a specific poll relevant to the article's topic.

annotations.paragraph: The survey found that only 2% of Trump voters regret their choice and would “vote differently” now if they could.
annotations.reason: Provides specific data supporting the claim of Trump's enduring support.

annotations.paragraph: That’s telling and speaks to more lasting support for the president and his agenda.
annotations.reason: Offers analysis on the significance of the survey data.

annotations.paragraph: Another telling number is that only 1% of Trump voters say they’d rather not have voted at all. Yet, when it comes to Kamala Harris, the former vice president and Democratic nominee, 14% of her voters say they’d rather have not taken part.
annotations.reason: Provides comparative data between Trump and Harris voters.

annotations.paragraph: CNN data analyst Harry Enten said this poll belies a common refrain in the media that a lot of Republicans regret voting for Trump.
annotations.reason: Includes expert commentary on the poll's implications.

annotations.paragraph: “So the bottom line is this: If there’s some idea out there that Trump voters are going around, ‘Man, I wish I had voted for Kamala Harris instead of Donald Trump,’ the numbers say that is a fanciful universe,” Enten observed. “It really, for the most part, does not exist.”
annotations.reason: Provides a direct quote reinforcing the article's main argument.

annotations.paragraph: This fairytale, in which any conservative would have been persuaded to vote for a true-blue progressive like Harris, is annoying to say the least.
annotations.reason: The paragraph is a subjective opinion without new information or context related to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: Yet, I have heard from many Democrats in recent months, scolding me for not having the “virtue” to support their candidate. Every time Trump does something they don’t like (which is all the time), I get angry emails saying “you voted for this.”
annotations.reason: The paragraph provides anecdotal evidence of partisan reactions but does not contribute directly to the main premise.

annotations.paragraph: For one thing, I never said whom I voted for, because it’s no one’s business but mine. In this role, I advocate for a set of principles I believe in – and I make decisions on whom to support based on how the candidate aligns with my beliefs.
annotations.reason: The paragraph is personal commentary and does not add new information relevant to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: No one is perfect. Trump isn’t perfect. And I disagree with plenty that he’s done and the way in which he’s done it, most strongly on the tariffs.
annotations.reason: The paragraph provides a critique of Trump but lacks direct relevance to the election rematch premise.

annotations.paragraph: There’s a much higher chance, however, that Trump will do something I support than Harris or Biden would have.
annotations.reason: The paragraph directly addresses the likelihood of Trump being favored over Harris or Biden, aligning with the headline.

annotations.paragraph: And Democrats have only themselves to blame for the Trump−Harris matchup. After they spent years lying to the American people about Biden’s health, they swapped Harris for Biden in a last-minute ploy that voters didn’t appreciate.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context and commentary on the political strategy and decisions leading to the Trump-Harris matchup.

annotations.paragraph: Harris compounded the problem with her inability to put two coherent sentences together or to differentiate herself from her boss.
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers specific criticism of Harris's communication skills, relevant to the election matchup.

annotations.paragraph: She would have been a terrible president, and not the president we needed to secure the border or strengthen the economy, which faltered under the Biden-Harris White House.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides an opinion on Harris's potential presidency and its impact on key issues.

annotations.paragraph: Voters who chose Trump put a lot of faith in his ability to fix these things.
annotations.reason: This paragraph discusses voter expectations of Trump, relevant to the election context.

annotations.paragraph: He must not let them down.
annotations.reason: This is a general statement without new information or context.

annotations.paragraph: Ingrid Jacques is a columnist at USA TODAY. Contact her at ijacques@usatoday.com or on X: @Ingrid_Jacques
annotations.reason: This is author contact information and does not contribute to the article's core story.
